content.text: State **two** other scalar quantities and **two** other vector quantities
State **two** properties that are possessed by both scalar and vector physical quantities
A property of a vector quantity, that is not a property of a scalar quantity, is direction
For example, velocity has direction but speed does not
Determine the magnitudes of the components of the velocity of the ship in the north and the east directions
north component of velocity =   .........  \(\text{ms}^{-1}\)
east component of velocity =   .........  \(\text{ms}^{-1}\)
The ship now experiences a tidal current. The water in the sea moves with a velocity of \(2.7 \text{m s}^{-1}\) to the west
Calculate the resultant velocity component of the ship in the east direction
resultant east component of velocity =   .........  \(\text{ms}^{-1}\)
Use your answers in (b)(i) and (b)(ii) to determine the magnitude of the resultant velocity of the ship
magnitude of resultant velocity =   .........  \(\text{ms}^{-1}\)
Use your answers in (b)(i) and (b)(ii) to determine the angle between north and the resultant velocity of the ship
A ship at sea is travelling with a velocity of \(13\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) in a direction \(35^{\circ}\) east of north in still water, as shown in Fig. 1.1
Define acceleration
Explain, with reference to forces acting on the stone, the shape of the curve in Fig. 2.1
Use Fig. 2.1 to determine the speed of the stone when the resultant force on it is zero
Use Fig. 2.1 to calculate the approximate height through which the stone falls between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 30 \text{s}\)
height =   .........  m
On Fig. 2.2, sketch the variation with \(t\) of the acceleration \(a\) of the stone between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 30 \text{s}\)
A stone falls vertically from the top of a cliff. Fig. 2.1 shows the variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) of the stone
Define the moment of a force about a point
Show that the increase in the length of the spring is approximately \(1.3 \text{mm}\)
Calculate the magnitude of the moment about the pivot of the weight of the object
moment =   .........  Nm
Use your answer in (b)(ii) to determine the increase in the tension in the spring due to the \(0.472\mathrm{kg}\) mass
increase in tension =   .........  N
Use the information in (b)(i) and your answer in (b)(iii) to determine the spring constant \(k\) of the spring. Give a unit with your answer
Fig. 3.1 shows a type of balance that is used for measuring mass
A rigid rod is pivoted about a point \(6.2 \text{cm}\) from the centre of a pan which is attached to one end. The object being measured is placed on the centre of this pan
A spring, attached to the rod \(1.8 \text{cm}\) from the pivot, is attached at its other end to a fixed point P. The spring obeys Hooke's law over the full range of operation of the balance
A pointer, on the other side of the pivot, is set against a millimetre scale which is a distance \(52.6 \text{cm}\) from the pivot
When the system is in equilibrium with no mass on the pan, the rod is horizontal and the pointer indicates a reading on the scale of \(86 \text{mm}\)
An object of mass \(0.472 \text{kg}\) is now placed on the pan. As a result, the pointer moves to indicate a reading of \(123 \text{mm}\) on the scale when the system is again in equilibrium
State the principle of superposition
Two waves, with intensities \(I\) and \(4I\), superpose. The waves have the same frequency
Determine, in terms of \(I\), the maximum possible intensity of the resulting wave
maximum intensity =   .........  \(I\)
Determine the distance between the centres of adjacent bright fringes on the screen
distance =   .........  m
The light of wavelength \(550 \text{nm}\) is replaced with red light of a single frequency
State and explain the change, if any, in the distance between the centres of adjacent bright fringes

Coherent light of wavelength \(550 \text{nm}\) is incident normally on a double slit of slit separation \(0.35 \text{mm}\). A series of bright and dark fringes forms on a screen placed a distance of \(1.2 \text{m}\) from the double slit, as shown in Fig. 4.1. The screen is parallel to the double slit
Define the _electromotive force_ (e.m.f.) of a source
The circuit shown in Fig. 5.1 contains a battery of e.m.f. \(E\) that has internal resistance \(r\), a variable resistor, a voltmeter and an ammeter

Readings from the two meters are taken for different settings of the variable resistor. The variation with current \(I\) of the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across the terminals XY of the battery is shown in Fig. 5.2
the e.m.f. \(E\)
the maximum current that the battery can supply
maximum current =   .........  A
the internal resistance \(r\)
For the battery in **(b)**, use Fig. 5.2 to determine:

On Fig. 5.2, sketch a line to show a possible variation with \(I\) of \(V\) for a battery with a lower e.m.f. and a lower internal resistance than the battery in **(b)**. Your line should extend over at least the same range of currents as the original line
a proton
a neutron
an alpha-particle
State the quark composition of:
the observation that most alpha-particles pass through the foil
the observation that some alpha-particles are scattered through angles greater than \(90^{\circ}\)
In the alpha-particle scattering experiment, alpha-particles were directed at a thin gold foil
State what may be inferred from:
A proton and an alpha-particle are moving in the same uniform electric field
Determine the ratio
acceleration of proton due to the electric field acceleration of alpha-particle due to the electric field
